The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" and the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004" prohibit trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The "Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004" and the "Anti-counterfeiting Amendments Act of 2004" prohibit trafficking in counterfeit components under Section 2318 of title 18, United States Code. The act specifies penalties for knowingly trafficking in counterfeit labels or illicit labels affixed to various types of works, including phonorecords, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and visual art. Penalties include fines or imprisonment for up to 5 years. The term 'illicit label' refers to a genuine labeling component used by the copyright owner to verify that a work is not counterfeit or infringing any copyright. It includes certificates, licensing documents, or registration cards. Illicit labels distributed without authorization can lead to penalties under the Intellectual Property Protection and Courts Amendments Act of 2004. The term 'counterfeit documentation or packaging' refers to falsified documentation or packaging that appears genuine but is not, used to designate a higher number of licensed users or copies than authorized by the copyright owner. It includes physical documentation or packaging for various types of works. The text discusses the illegal affixing of counterfeit or illicit labels to copyrighted works such as sound recordings, computer programs, literary works, and visual art. It also mentions civil remedies for such actions under Title 18 of the United States Code. The text discusses civil remedies for copyright infringement, allowing copyright owners to bring a civil action in court for violations. The court has the discretion to grant injunctions, impound infringing articles, and award attorney fees, costs, actual damages, and additional profits to the injured party. The injured party is entitled to recover actual damages and profits from the violator for copyright infringement. Actual damages are calculated by multiplying the value of infringing items by the quantity of items involved. The value of a phonorecord, copy, or work of visual art is determined by the retail value of an authorized copy of the copyrighted material, such as sound recordings, computer programs, motion pictures, literary works, and pictorial/graphic/sculptural works. The Copyright Act allows for statutory damages ranging from $2,500 to $25,000 for each violation of copyright infringement. The court may triple the damages for subsequent violations within 3 years. A civil action must be initiated within 3 years of discovering the infringement. The item relating to section 2318 in the table of sections for chapter 113 of title 18, United States Code, is amended to read as follows: "2318. Trafficking in counterfeit labels, illicit labels, or counterfeit documentation or packaging." SEC. 103. OTHER RIGHTS NOT AFFECTED. The amendments made by this title do not affect liability or limitations under sections 512, 1201, or 1202 of Title 17, United States Code. They also do not apply to electronic transmissions of genuine certificates or counterfeit labels under Title 18. Fair use under section 107 of Title 17 is not affected by these amendments. The curr_chunk discusses the requirement for genuine certificates, licensing documents, registration cards, or similar labeling components as described in section 2318(b) of Title 18, United States Code. The "Fraudulent Online Identity Sanctions Act" under Title II introduces amendments to the Trademark Act of 1946, establishing a rebuttable presumption of willful violation if false contact information is knowingly provided during domain name registration. SEC. 203. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 17, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 504(c) of title 17, United States Code, is amended to include a rebuttable presumption of willful infringement in cases where false contact information is knowingly provided to domain name authorities. This does not limit what can be considered willful infringement under the law. The term 'domain name' is defined in the Trademark Act of 1946. SEC. 204. AMENDMENT TO TITLE 18, UNITED STATES CODE. Section 3559 of title 18, United States Code is amended to include a sentencing enhancement for individuals convicted of falsely registering a domain name and using it in the commission of a felony offense. The maximum imprisonment for the offense will be doubled or increased by 7 years, whichever is less. The terms "falsely registers" and "domain name" are defined within the section. The United States Sentencing Commission is directed to review and amend sentencing guidelines to ensure harsh penalties for individuals convicted of felony offenses facilitated by providing false contact information to register a domain name. The term "domain name" is defined in section 45 of the Trademark Act of 1946 as used in this subsection. SEC. 205. CONSTRUCTION. This section clarifies that the rights of free speech and press are not affected by activities related to domain name registration. It also emphasizes that courts have discretion in determining damages, relief, and terms of imprisonment for intellectual property rights infringement. 

TITLE III--COURTS. Amendments are made to the United States Code regarding additional places for holding court in Colorado and the Northern District of New York.
